A short but sweet experience. You'll progress through 11 chapters comprised of puzzle rooms and an admittedly simple boss fight. The story is pretty good but takes a backseat to gameplay. The puzzles aren't very challenging but will keep your attention. The game also has challenge rooms and time trials in a separate mode if you want more than the main story has to offer. Overall, its a good game.

It's Portal. Adds some context for Portal 2, so it's worth a playthrough although it's pretty short.

good but ign said When students from DigiPen showed off their project Narbacular Drop to a room full of Valve personell, they probably didn't expect that they would not only be hired, but given a budget to expand that idea into something as special as we see with Portal. It's quirky, clever, polished, and presented with a spark of a subtly evil humor that it's hard not to enjoy the quick romp through Aperture Laboratories. The problem is that it is so quick. Players wanting to get their money's worth will want to play through again and definitely check out the challenges.

Portal uses a concept that's a bit hard to wrap your head around without actually seeing it in action. The only "weapon" you're given is a portal gun that can shoot a portal entrance with the right mouse button and a portal exit with the left mouse button. Once both portals have been placed, you can walk though the entrance and find yourself at the exit. Walk through the exit and you're back at the entrance. The portals can be shot across a distance but only on certain surfaces, which creates the puzzle atmosphere. You'll have to figure out how to get across chasms, up and over obstacles, and around automated turrets. The trick is that you can only have one entrance and one exit meaning sometimes you'll encounter several kinds of brain teasers on how to use the portals correctly, and in some cases, quickly and often. It'll make you think about which portal you're placing, the exact location of where it needs to go, and the timing of when portals need to be switched.
The fun thing about many of these puzzles is that you're not the only thing that can move through these portals. The weighted companion blocks can be used to take out turrets by placing a portal over the turret's head and another under a block. Energy spheres (like those found in Half-Life 2) are used frequently where players have to negotiate their path using portals to activate a switch. There are some really fun uses of the portals here, especially in all of those strange moments where you can see yourself through a portal across the room entering the portal you're stepping through. It's pretty easy to find yourself plopping portals on the ceiling and the floor to go into a constant freefall or place two portals in the corner of the room and chase your own tail. Very bizarre.



The main problem with the game is that it's so short. While what's there can certainly be satisfying, we shot through the first 15 levels of the game in about 30 minutes with the last four taking up a bit over an hour. We really wish those first 15 missions had been squished into a couple of quick missions to teach the basics and then had the following 17 missions really up the ante. We know they can do it after playing some of their sadistic advanced versions of six of the levels from the game that (in most cases) are much more difficult than the originals. We would have loved to have seen more of that throughout the game rather than the very long string of basic tutorial type levels.

The story is best left unspoiled (mostly because saying anything might give what little there is away) but is built like a short story from a novelist. It's a piece of a bigger puzzle and one that while tiny is certainly entertaining as it goes. There are little clues here and there hinting at what you, an older Asian woman, are doing in Aperture Labs and even more clues on how this all relates to the Half-Life universe.

Absolutely outstanding game that started it all. Even in 2021, the graphics and gameplay do not hinder the experience. Warning: the game will be VERY short, especially if you know what you're doing. Portal 2 is a much longer game in terms of puzzles, content, and story. However, for $10, you will 100% get your money's worth.

I have the second version of this game, Portal 2, in addition to the original Portal. I actually purchased the second version first, and I love Portal's game-play and story-line. Both versions are very good games, Valve gets a thumbs up. However I think they could go back to the drawing board with additional testing in the first version. For some players prone to motion sickness, the game can make you nauseous and dizzy. I believe Valve has corrected this in the second version, and it may be better for some players in that aspect than the original. I got very nauseous and dizzy after about an hour in the first version and never had any nausea playing the second version in both the co-op and single player game modes. If you are sensitive to motion or prone to motion sickness in general or with a virtual reality headset, I recommend purchasing the second version, Portal 2, over the original Portal for a less nauseous experience and more consistent frame rate during play.

Just a fun and simple puzzle game that anyone can play. with it's iconic Valve level design and story telling you cant go wrong with this classic. As you play this game you will be scared out your mind. As you go through Aperture Sciences meany test chambers and uncover its dark mysteries. All while an omnipotent robotic voice comments on they way you complete some of the tests with witty remarks about you and game play mechanics for example "SPEEDY THING GOES IN SPEEDY THING GOES OUT" witch refers to the momentum mechanic this helps teach the player how to swing through portal from portal witch is what this game strides for and will be consistent throughout the experience.

This game can really make you feel alone and the sound track really helps this point come across even better. The sterile and modern/futuristic environments can really make things seem alien to the player as well. This also helps you think out side the box as you will be completing complex puzzles that will enhance you problem solving skills your missing out if you have not played this game so pick it up there is a reason way people sill quote "the cake is a lie" till this very day.
